timeline.bodyText:

Then - these properties are going to be used for testing in any environment, right?

replies.bodyText: Yes, We can use these in any environment. Should I create a new gradle-dhs.properties file?
replies.author: SameeraPriyathamTadikonda

replies.bodyText: Keep them in here - they have to exist in gradle.properties so that you can reference them in build.gradle. The only reason for a "gradle-env.properties" file is if there's an "env" that we want to configure properties for. That isn't the case and likely won't be for this project. We'll always use e.g. "-P" to pass in env-specific properties for things like a Jenkins environment.
replies.author: rjrudin

timeline.bodyText: Assuming you're using Intellij, be sure to do a Reformat Code on every file - I have option-command-L as a shortcut for that, I forget if it's a default in Intellij. That'll ensure that we don't get a bunch of changes to this file in another PR when someone does run Reformat Code.
timeline.author: rjrudin

timeline.bodyText: For consistency with other DHF props, do "hubDhs" and "isDhs" (that's consistent with "Ssl", for example).
